title: Pottery and some briquetage were discovered in a brief examination of this site by F

A kiln or salt-pan discovered during quarrying, partially excavated before it was destroyed. It consisted of a large rectangular trough with a baked clay floor. Large quantities of briquetage and sherds ‘probably of the Gallo-Roman period’ were recovered
Briquetage site with well-preserved kiln bars and hand-bricks. One Iron Age coin was found and the site may be Iron Age or Roman in date

The remains of an early medieval long-house, dated by the pottery to c.AD 800–1150, were excavated just inland from the coast at Cobo. The finds also included a possible amphora sherd, a fragment of Roman tile and two pieces of briquetage
Iron Age and early Roman settlement discovered and partly excavated in the 1970s and again in
It was occupied from c.80 BC – AD 50 and comprised circular post-built houses enclosed by palisaded ditches. The site extends over a considerable area
St Saviour (MGU2527 and MGU2541

Large quantities of briquetage are present in Guernsey Museum from an otherwise unrecorded investigation at this site in 1949. Decreasing amounts have been recovered in two excavations since then, and much of the site has now been lost to coastal erosion. See also B32
18–20 The Pollet, St Peter Port (MGU543
Excavations on this site revealed large quantities of medieval and post-medieval pottery. There were also five sherds of samian pottery

A settlement and cemetery dating from the early Iron Age through to the end of the 1st millennium BC. The presence of Roman material, including a complete samian dish stamped HONORATI, indicates a later occupation of the site
References: Burns, Cunliffe and Sebire 1996 (1980s excavations
St Peter Port (MGU2216
Romano-Celtic vessel wrecked c.AD 280 following a fire on board. At the time of writing this was the most substantial sea-going vessel of the Roman era surviving outside the Mediterranean

note: Two possible Roman sherds were found here. Reference: de Jersey 2013.
title: The excavated part of this coastal medieval settlement comprised three stone buildings set around a courtyard. There is evidence of further buildings and enclosures on the headland
Most of the finds from this town site were medieval and post-medieval, but there were also 14 sherds of Roman pottery
St Peter Port (MGU541
Urban site with mainly medieval and post-medieval finds, but including one Roman brick or tile fragment

plus several spot finds) In addition to briquetage, this Iron Age/Roman salt-working site on the eastern side of the Fort Grey islet has yielded five sherds of possible Roman pottery and two fragments of tile

Essentially an occupation site of the Early Neolithic and Bronze Age periods, but close to the Roman waterfront, and 231 pieces of Roman pottery and tile (most quite small and some water-rounded) plus 290 small scraps that were possibly Roman were found during excavations
Three sherds of samian pottery were recovered from this Late Neolithic and Bronze Age occupation site, plus a spindle whorl probably fashioned from a Roman flagon base
Gallo-Roman deposits were identified beneath the demolished Savoy Hotel, including 68 Roman sherds and a small fragment of probable Roman glass

A structure resembling a prehistoric cist, but associated with medieval pottery and therefore thought to have been disturbed in the Middle Ages. Amongst the finds were two sherds of samian ware and part of a flagon, and two tile fragments
One Gallo-Roman rim sherd was found in a re-deposited context in trench A, adjacent to a midden exposure on the north coast of Jethou

Herm, various locations (excavated 2008–11) Roman pottery was discovered during excavations undertaken by Chris Scarre at various locations in the northern part of the island. The finds are currently being studied for publication

Archaeological investigation in advance of the airport runway development found evidence primarily of Neolithic and Bronze Age activity, but among the finds are some 29 Roman and possibly Roman sherds and four fragments of tegulae

Extensions to the quarry required an archaeological watching brief and a small excavation. Most of the material collected was prehistoric, but there were also two sherds of Roman greyware and three fragments probably of briquetage
A small archaeological excavation was carried out adjacent to the west door of the church, revealing three post-medieval burials. A sherd of samian pottery was found
Pottery finds from excavation of part of the medieval cemetery adjoining St Tugual’s Chapel included one definite and two possible Roman sherds
One small oxidized body sherd recovered during the excavation of a test-pit in the grounds of Le Tertre
Fragment of Roman tile found in a test-pit

note: in particular inside the building in the south wall near the altar. Reference: McCormack 2010, 720ff.

St Sampson Parish Church: brick (MGU1372) John McCormack (pers. comm.) has reported that there are two small pieces of Roman brick in the south and east walls of the church
Castel Parish Church: brick, tile (MGU3549
A considerable quantity of Roman brick, tile and opus signinum was recovered from the spoil of a 44m trench dug for a new water pipe on the north side of the church

A single Roman sherd recorded from a destroyed dolmen at Grosse Hougue

Three sherds of a samian mortarium, probably made in central Gaul in the late 2nd century AD. The soil on parts of the Grandes Rocques headland has been re-deposited and these sherds may have originated elsewhere in the island
Vale: pottery, figurine (MGU2223
Eleven sherds of Roman pottery and part of a pipe clay figurine were discovered during the construction of a car park

Eleven sherds of Roman pottery, including four samian sherds, were found in sand dredged from the main harbour, and thus probably recently re-deposited
